stem: The radiation safety nurse is triaging victims from a nuclear power plant accident. Based on the documentation in the Radiation Exposure & Decontamination Log, match each finding with its priority nursing intervention.

tabs.title: Incident Overview
tabs.content:
06:00: Accidental release of radioactive Iodine-131 and Cesium-137.
07:00: Victims arriving at the hospital perimeter. External Geiger counter readings are high for several individuals.
08:00: Decontamination showers established outside the building.

tabs.title: Radiation Exposure & Decontamination Log
tabs.content:
VictimContamination TypeClock TimeSymptom Onset
AExternal (Clothing/Skin)08:15None yet
BInternal (Ingested/Inhaled)08:30Nausea / Vomiting
CMixed (Open wound)08:45Radiation Burn

tabs.title: Clinical Status
tabs.content:
Victim B: Early vomiting (within 1 hour) is a poor prognostic sign for Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS).
Victim A: Geiger readings dropped 90% after clothing removal.

rows.text: External radioactivity on clothing and skin
Known or suspected ingestion of radioactive Iodine-131
Radioactive particles trapped in an open wound

columns.text: Priority: Removal of clothing and soap/water decontamination
Priority: Immediate irrigation and coverage with occlusive dressing
Priority: Aggressive triage for acute radiation syndrome (ARS)

rationale.correct: External contamination (r1) is managed by stripping clothing (removes 90% of particles) and a mild soap/water wash (c1). Radioactive iodine ingestion (r2) requires potassium iodide (KI) to block thyroid uptake (c2). Wounds (r3) must be irrigated carefully (c3). Rapid symptom onset like vomiting (r4) indicates a high dose of radiation and requires immediate assessment for ARS (c4).
clinicalPearls: Potassium iodide (KI) only protects the thyroid; it doesn't help with external burns.
Vomiting within 30-60 minutes after a nuclear event is a sign of a LETHAL dose.
Decontaminate from LEAST contaminated to MOST contaminated if possible, but keep wastewater contained.

questionTrap.trap: Bringing the radioactive patient into the regular ED waiting room.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NEVER. Radiation victims are decontaminated OUTSIDE or in a specialized 'hot zone' before they enter the medical area.
